elements.content: With the guidance of the hard/soft acid/base principle, we adopt a strategy to construct a novel robust metal–organic framework (MOF) by using a dual-functional ligand to coordinate with different types of metal ions in a one-pot reaction through coordination self-selection. A bimetallic MOF, namely BUT-85 (BUT = Beijing University of Technology), has been successfully synthesized with a rationally designed pyrazolate-carboxylate ligand. Its robust [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chain (Pz = pyrazolate) with bridging OH–/H2O and pyrazolate groups is reported for the first time. This material shows good chemical stability in water and aqueous solutions with a pH range from 3 to 13. In addition, BUT-85 exhibits preferential adsorption behavior of C2H2 over CO2. It is proposed to be attributed to the abundant exposed bridging OH–/H2O sites in [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chains, which is supported by the results of molecular simulations. Column breakthrough experiments further confirm that this MOF can realize efficient C2H2/CO2 separation. This strategy can not only enrich the structural library of MOFs but also optimize their properties and functions for promoting applications.
elements.clean_text:
With the guidance of the hard/soft
acid/base principle, we adopt
a strategy to construct a novel robust metal–organic framework
(MOF) by using a dual-functional ligand to coordinate with different
types of metal ions in a one-pot reaction through coordination self-selection.
A bimetallic MOF, namely BUT-85 (BUT = Beijing University
of Technology), has been successfully synthesized with a rationally
designed pyrazolate-carboxylate ligand. Its robust [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3]
n
 chain (Pz = pyrazolate) with bridging OH–/H2O and pyrazolate groups is reported for the first time.
This material shows good chemical stability in water and aqueous solutions
with a pH range from 3 to 13. In addition, BUT-85 exhibits
preferential adsorption behavior of C2H2 over
CO2. It is proposed to be attributed to the abundant exposed
bridging OH–/H2O sites in [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3]
n
 chains, which is supported by the results of molecular simulations.
Column breakthrough experiments further confirm that this MOF can
realize efficient C2H2/CO2 separation.
This strategy can not only enrich the structural library of MOFs but
also optimize their properties and functions for promoting applications.

other properties: good chemical stability in water and aqueous solutions with a pH range from 3 to 13
preferential adsorption behavior of C2H2 over CO2

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as a new class of crystalline materials, have attracted intense attention for their high surface area, porosity and structural tunability. The secondary building units (SBUs) and the bridging organic ligands act as the key components in MOFs and endow the materials with tunable porous structures and diverse functions. SBUs also provide the possibility to modulate the physicochemical properties of MOFs. In the past decades, the application potentials of MOFs in various fields have been extensively explored and solidly confirmed, such as gas separation/storage, catalysis, sensing and so on. To ensure the long cycling life and good working performance of MOFs in these application scenarios, their stability becomes a prerequisite requirement. Thus, developing new methods to synthesize stable MOFs and enrich the structural library is a sought-after goal to further expand the utilization ranges of MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Metal–organic frameworks
(MOFs), as a new class of crystalline materials, have attracted intense
attention for their high surface area, porosity and structural tunability. The secondary building units (SBUs) and the bridging organic ligands
act as the key components in MOFs and endow the materials with tunable
porous structures and diverse functions. SBUs also provide the possibility
to modulate the physicochemical properties of MOFs. In the past
decades, the application potentials of MOFs in various fields have
been extensively explored and solidly confirmed, such as gas separation/storage,
catalysis, sensing and so on. To ensure the long cycling life and good working performance of
MOFs in these application scenarios, their stability becomes a prerequisite
requirement. Thus, developing new methods
to synthesize stable MOFs and enrich the structural library is a sought-after
goal to further expand the utilization ranges of MOFs.

elements.content: Conventional synthesis of MOFs was through the solvothermal reactions of metal salts and ligands with one type of coordination groups, such as carboxylate or azolate groups. The structures of MOFs are mainly determined by the crystal growth conditions and the geometries of the ligands. However, the synthesis of complicated ligands and the adjustment of solvothermal conditions could be costly and time-consuming, which makes the extension of the structural library of stable MOFs challenging. According to the hard/soft acid/base (HSAB) principle, the hard bases, such as carboxylate groups, have a higher affinity toward high-valent metal ions, while the soft bases, like azoles, can form stronger coordination bonds with low-valent transition metal ions. Therefore, when we try to utilize dual-functional pyrazolate-carboxylate ligands to construct MOFs with both high- and low-valent metal ions, it is reasonable for these two types of coordination groups to form stable SBUs with their respective favored metal ions. Through this coordination self-selection, we can not only obtain robust MOFs but also discover some SBUs with novel geometrical and topological characters, which might be formed to achieve the structural compatibility of the ligand and the different SBUs in a single framework. These SBUs may possess special properties and can promote the applications of MOFs in different fields.
elements.clean_text:
Conventional synthesis of MOFs was through
the solvothermal reactions
of metal salts and ligands with one type of coordination groups, such
as carboxylate or azolate groups. The structures of MOFs
are mainly determined by the crystal growth conditions and the geometries
of the ligands. However, the synthesis of complicated
ligands and the adjustment of solvothermal conditions could be costly
and time-consuming, which makes the extension of the structural library
of stable MOFs challenging. According
to the hard/soft acid/base (HSAB) principle, the hard bases, such
as carboxylate groups, have a higher affinity toward high-valent metal
ions, while the soft bases, like azoles, can form stronger coordination
bonds with low-valent transition metal ions. Therefore, when we try to utilize dual-functional pyrazolate-carboxylate
ligands to construct MOFs with both high- and low-valent metal ions,
it is reasonable for these two types of coordination groups to form
stable SBUs with their respective favored metal ions. Through this coordination self-selection, we can not only obtain
robust MOFs but also discover some SBUs with novel geometrical and
topological characters, which might be formed to achieve the structural
compatibility of the ligand and the different SBUs in a single framework.
These SBUs may possess special properties and can promote the applications
of MOFs in different fields.

elements.content: Herein, on the basis of the HSAB principle, we have successfully synthesized a bimetallic MOF (BUT-85, BUT = Beijing University of Technology) with two types of SBUs through the solvothermal reactions of a simple dual-functional ligand 4-(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­benzoic acid (H2PBA), Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O and Yb­(NO3)3·5H2O. This MOF is constructed by robust [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chains (Pz = pyrazolate) and Yb cluster chains. It shows good chemical stability in water and aqueous solutions with a pH range from 3 to 13. BUT-85 exhibited preferential adsorption behavior of C2H2 over CO2. It was proposed to be attributed to the abundant exposed bridging OH–/H2O sites in [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chains, which was supported by the results of molecular simulations. Furthermore, column breakthrough experiments confirmed that this material could realize efficient C2H2/CO2 separation.
elements.clean_text:
Herein, on the basis of the HSAB
principle, we have successfully
synthesized a bimetallic MOF (BUT-85, BUT = Beijing University
of Technology) with two types of SBUs through the solvothermal reactions
of a simple dual-functional ligand 4-(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­benzoic
acid (H2PBA), Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O and Yb­(NO3)3·5H2O.
This MOF is constructed by robust [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3]
n
 chains
(Pz = pyrazolate) and Yb cluster chains. It shows good chemical stability
in water and aqueous solutions with a pH range from 3 to 13. BUT-85 exhibited preferential adsorption behavior of C2H2 over CO2. It was proposed to be attributed
to the abundant exposed bridging OH–/H2O sites in [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3]
n
 chains, which was supported
by the results of molecular simulations. Furthermore, column breakthrough
experiments confirmed that this material could realize efficient C2H2/CO2 separation.

elements.content: It is well-known that the rare-earth-carboxylate MOFs, especially the ones with SBUs of single metal nodes or common one-dimensional chains, are more prevalent in the literature, but most of them are unstable in water. Aiming to increase the chemical stability of MOFs, we tried to construct polynuclear rare-earth metal cluster SBUs. It is proposed that the use of 2-fluorobenzoic acid (2-FBA) could control the hydrolysis of the rare-earth precursor and induce the formation of polynuclear rare-earth metal clusters or their derived SBUs. Finally, the self-assembly of H2PBA with Yb3+ and Ni2+ resulted in BUT-85, C30N6O16H18Yb3Ni2, as green crystals by employing 2-FBA during the solvothermal reaction. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analysis revealed that BUT-85 crystallizes in trigonal P3̅ space group (No. 147). Two crystallographically independent Ni atoms coordinate with three pyrazolates from three different PBA2– ligands. This Ni2 node is connected with two adjacent nodes through six bridging O atoms to form a straight [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chain along the c-axis (b). Six Yb3+ ions coordinate with six carboxylates and eight bridging O atoms to form a Yb6O8 cluster, which is interconnected with two adjacent clusters through 12 O atoms to further create hybrid Yb cluster chains (b). Then, the Yb cluster chains are connected with six adjacent [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chains by the PBA2– ligands to give a 3D framework structure of BUT-85. A view along the c-axis reveals diamond-shaped channels with diagonal distances of 17.06 × 9.73 Å (a). After the removal of free solvents, the total accessible volume of BUT-85 is estimated to be 55.2% by PLATON. To the best of our knowledge, the [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chain is reported for the first time in MOFs, in which the coordination mode of Ni2+ is also very rare. We proposed the formation of this special [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chain is to match the coordination step lengths of the Yb cluster chain. As shown in b,c, the length of the repeat unit of Yb cluster chain is 6.553 Å, while the length of common chain formed by Ni2+ and pyrazolate groups is 6.765 Å. Therefore, the bridging oxygen atoms are inserted into the Ni-Pz chain to make these two SBUs compatible in the same framework. The construction of BUT-85 from such a dual-functional organic ligand provides a showcase for diversifying the structures of bimetallic MOFs by forming novel SBUs. It should be noticed that bridging OH–/H2O in [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chains are forced to be exposed to the channel to satisfy the octahedral geometry of Ni atoms, which would be ideal sites to bind gas molecules. Topologically, each Ni2 node and Yb6 cluster can be simplified as 5- and 8-connected nodes, thus the 3D framework of BUT-85 can be considered as a (5,8)-connected net with the point symbol of {418.610}­{49.6}2, which corresponds to the kag-d topology (Figure S5).

(c) Reported common Ni-Pz chain with bridging pyrazolate groups. Color code: Yb, azure; Ni, green; O, red; N, blue; C, black; hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The permanent porosity of BUT-85 was determined by N2 sorption measurements at 77 K. As shown in a, the saturated N2 uptake of BUT-85 is 204.8 cm3 g–1, and its evaluated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area reaches 730.3 m2 g–1. On the basis of the N2 adsorption data, the pore size distribution of BUT-85 is evaluated to be in the range of 9.9–13.4 Å by the calculation with a nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) model, being close to the result of crystallographic structure analysis (Figure S10).
elements.clean_text:
The permanent porosity of BUT-85 was determined by
N2 sorption measurements at 77 K. As shown in a, the saturated
N2 uptake of BUT-85 is 204.8 cm3 g–1, and its evaluated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller
surface area reaches 730.3 m2 g–1. On
the basis of the N2 adsorption data, the pore size distribution
of BUT-85 is evaluated to be in the range of 9.9–13.4
Å by the calculation with a nonlocal density functional theory
(NLDFT) model, being close to the result of crystallographic structure
analysis (Figure S10).

elements.content: To further explore the properties of BUT-85, its thermal and chemical stabilities were evaluated based on thermogravimetric curves, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns and N2 isotherms. As shown in Figure S8, this bimetallic MOF can be stable in the air up to 400 °C, demonstrating its good thermal stability. Then, the chemical stability of BUT-85 was tested by soaking activated MOF samples in different aqueous solutions. As shown in a,b, after being immersed into water or aqueous solutions with pH of 3 and 13, the PXRD peak intensities and N2 uptakes of the treated samples remain almost unchanged, further indicating the high chemical resistance of BUT-85.
elements.clean_text:
To further explore the properties of BUT-85, its thermal
and chemical stabilities were evaluated based on thermogravimetric
curves, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns and N2 isotherms. As shown in Figure S8, this
bimetallic MOF can be stable in the air up to 400 °C, demonstrating
its good thermal stability. Then, the chemical stability of BUT-85 was tested by soaking activated MOF samples in different
aqueous solutions. As shown in a,b, after being immersed into water or aqueous solutions
with pH of 3 and 13, the PXRD peak intensities and N2 uptakes
of the treated samples remain almost unchanged, further indicating
the high chemical resistance of BUT-85.

elements.content: It is well-known that rare-earth-carboxylate MOFs are generally labile to water because the weak coordination bonds would accelerate the substitution reaction of water molecules to organic ligands. Therefore, we speculate that the good acid/base stability of BUT-85 may be mainly attributed to the robust [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chain and rare-earth cluster chain SBUs. After 40 mg of BUT-85 was soaked in 50 mL of water at room temperature for 24 h, the residual solution was taken for inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) measurements. The concentrations of Yb3+ (6.38 × 10–6 mg mL–1) and Ni2+ (3.45 × 10–6 mg mL–1) were detected in the solution, demonstrating almost no metal ion was leaked out from BUT-85. This result further confirmed the good chemical stability of BUT-85 in water and its potential to be exploited in significant applications.
elements.clean_text:
It is well-known
that rare-earth-carboxylate MOFs are generally
labile to water because the weak coordination bonds would accelerate
the substitution reaction of water molecules to organic ligands. Therefore, we speculate that the good acid/base
stability of BUT-85 may be mainly attributed to the robust
[Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3]
n
 chain and rare-earth cluster chain SBUs.
After 40 mg of BUT-85 was soaked in 50 mL of water at
room temperature for 24 h, the residual solution was taken for inductively
coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) measurements.
The concentrations of Yb3+ (6.38 × 10–6 mg mL–1) and Ni2+ (3.45 × 10–6 mg mL–1) were detected in the solution,
demonstrating almost no metal ion was leaked out from BUT-85. This result further confirmed the good chemical stability of BUT-85 in water and its potential to be exploited in significant
applications.

elements.content: The abundant exposed bridging OH–/H2O and good chemical stability of BUT-85 suggest that it could be a good sorbent candidate for gases. In addition, the C2H2/CO2 separation is particularly important in the industry but challenging because of their similar physical properties and molecular shapes/sizes, in which porous MOF materials have great potential. Single-component adsorption isotherms of BUT-85 for C2H2 and CO2 were measured at 298 and 273 K. As illustrated in a, at 298 K and 101.325 kPa, BUT-85 shows 66.01 and 28.84 cm3 g–1 of C2H2 and CO2 uptakes, respectively, affording preferential adsorption of C2H2 over CO2. The isosteric heats of adsorption (Q st) values for C2H2 and CO2 were calculated to be ∼35.4 and ∼16.6 kJ mol–1 in BUT-85, indicating this MOF has a strong C2H2 affinity, which can be comparable to other benchmark MOF materials (c and Table S2). Moreover, the gas selectivity of C2H2 over CO2 for BUT-85 was predicted by using the ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) on the binary mixture (50/50 volume ratio) based on single-component adsorption isotherms. As shown in b, the simulated C2H2/CO2 selectivity ranges between 6.1 and 12.1 for BUT-85. Particularly, this selectivity value exceeds those observed in most of other reported MOFs (Table S2). As presented in Figure S11, the cycling adsorption experiments revealed that BUT-85 could maintain its adsorption performances over at least three cycles. These results demonstrated the potential of BUT-85 in a practical application for C2H2/CO2 separation.

elements.content: To further probe the C2H2/CO2 separation performance of BUT-85 in the practical process, column breakthrough experiments were conducted. An equal proportion of mixed gases of C2H2/CO2 flowed through the packed column of activated MOF samples with a flow rate of 2 mL min–1 at 298 K. The experimental results presented in d revealed that CO2 passed through the fixed bed at first, whereas no C2H2 was found until a final dimensionless time of 178, demonstrating the successful separation of C2H2/CO2 mixture achieved by BUT-85. Remarkably, the C2H2 retention dimensionless time for BUT-85 (132) can be comparable to those of other MOF materials with good performance on C2H2/CO2 separation under the same conditions. In addition, BUT-85 could also maintain its separation performance and porous structure after three cycles, verifying the good recyclability of this MOF (Figure S16).
elements.clean_text:
To further probe the C2H2/CO2 separation
performance of BUT-85 in the practical process, column
breakthrough experiments were conducted. An equal proportion of mixed
gases of C2H2/CO2 flowed through
the packed column of activated MOF samples with a flow rate of 2 mL
min–1 at 298 K. The experimental results presented
in d revealed
that CO2 passed through the fixed bed at first, whereas
no C2H2 was found until a final dimensionless
time of 178, demonstrating the successful separation of C2H2/CO2 mixture achieved by BUT-85. Remarkably, the C2H2 retention dimensionless
time for BUT-85 (132) can be comparable to those of other
MOF materials with good performance on C2H2/CO2 separation under the same conditions. In addition, BUT-85 could also maintain its separation performance and
porous structure after three cycles, verifying the good recyclability
of this MOF (Figure S16).

elements.content: To understand the selective adsorption behavior of C2H2 over CO2 for BUT-85, grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations and density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out. As shown in Figure S17, the simulated adsorption isotherms for C2H2 and CO2 of BUT-85 matched well with the experimental ones, suggesting the reasonableness of the molecular simulation model built to understand the adsorption behavior of BUT-85. Both C2H2 and CO2 molecules preferentially occupy the bridging hydroxyl sites of the [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chains in the quadrilateral channels through van der Waals interactions (). As indicated, one CH···O (2.62 Å) and six CH···π (2.96–3.46 Å) interactions were found for each adsorbed C2H2 molecule. By contrast, CO2 exhibits two CO···H interactions (3.23–3.46 Å) and one CO···C interaction (3.58 Å) with one benzene ring. In addition, the calculated static C2H2 binding energy value is 31.5 kJ mol–1, considerably higher than the value of CO2 (19.2 kJ mol–1), which is similar to the experimental Q st values. These calculation results clearly proved that the exposed bridging hydroxyl sites of the [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chains could be strong C2H2 binding sites, thus promoting the selective adsorption of C2H2 over CO2 for BUT-85.

elements.content: In summary, with the guide of the HSAB principle, we explored a new method to synthesize a stable bimetallic MOF with a dual-functional pyrazolate-carboxylate ligand and different types of metal ions through coordination self-selection. Following this method, a robust MOF with two types of SBUs, [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chain and Yb cluster chain, was obtained. This MOF exhibited good chemical stability in both acidic and basic solutions. The novel [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chain was reported for the first time, which might be formed to match the coordination step length of the other Yb cluster chain inside the framework. In addition, BUT-85 showed preferential adsorption behavior of C2H2 over CO2. It was proposed to be attributed to the abundant exposed bridging OH–/H2O sites in [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3] n chains, which was supported by the results of molecular simulations. Column breakthrough experiments further confirmed that this MOF could realize efficient C2H2/CO2 separation. Insights from this work will assist in the construction of stable MOFs and enrich the structural library and encourage future research in expanding practical applications of MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
In summary, with the guide of the HSAB principle, we explored a
new method to synthesize a stable bimetallic MOF with a dual-functional
pyrazolate-carboxylate ligand and different types of metal ions through
coordination self-selection. Following this method, a robust MOF with
two types of SBUs, [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3]
n
 chain and Yb cluster
chain, was obtained. This MOF exhibited good chemical stability in
both acidic and basic solutions. The novel [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3]
n
 chain was reported for the first time, which might be formed to
match the coordination step length of the other Yb cluster chain inside
the framework. In addition, BUT-85 showed preferential
adsorption behavior of C2H2 over CO2. It was proposed to be attributed to the abundant exposed bridging
OH–/H2O sites in [Ni2(OH)­(H2O)2Pz3]
n
 chains, which was supported by the results of molecular simulations.
Column breakthrough experiments further confirmed that this MOF could
realize efficient C2H2/CO2 separation.
Insights from this work will assist in the construction of stable
MOFs and enrich the structural library and encourage future research
in expanding practical applications of MOFs.

metadata.title:
Stable Bimetallic Metal–Organic Framework with
Dual-Functional Pyrazolate-Carboxylate Ligand: Rational Construction
and C2H2/CO2 Separation
